question: Which novel by the author of Armada will adapted as a feature film by Steven Spielberg? And find similar flims if you found one.
ground_truth:
Ready Player One‚ÄîErnest Cline‚Äôs debut‚Äîwas adapted into a feature film by Steven Spielberg (released 2018).Ôøº

Similar films to check out
 ‚Ä¢ Tron: Legacy ‚Äî VR world quest
 ‚Ä¢ The Matrix ‚Äî simulated reality, rebellion
 ‚Ä¢ Free Guy ‚Äî NPC becomes self-aware in a game
 ‚Ä¢ Wreck-It Ralph ‚Äî gaming nostalgia crossover
 ‚Ä¢ Scott Pilgrim vs. the World ‚Äî game-style battles, pop-culture
 ‚Ä¢ Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle ‚Äî players trapped in a game
  ‚Ä¢ Ender‚Äôs Game ‚Äî training via games, sci-fi war
 ‚Ä¢ The Last Starfighter ‚Äî gamer recruited by aliens

Want picks closer to Armada‚Äôs ‚Äúgamer ‚Üí real alien war‚Äù vibe? Start with The Last Starfighter and Ender‚Äôs Game.

question: Tell me about MCP and A2A in AI agent. What is similar and not similar?
ground_truth:
**TL;DR**  
- **MCP** = standard way for an agent/app to discover & call **tools/resources/prompts** from *servers*.  
- **A2A** = standard way for **agents to talk to agents** (goals, state, results) across vendors.  
- They‚Äôre **complementary**: use **MCP** to expose capabilities; use **A2A** to coordinate multi-agent work.  

---

## One-liners
- **MCP (Model Context Protocol):** Open protocol (JSON-RPC based) for exposing *Tools, Resources, Prompts* from MCP servers so AI apps/agents can discover and invoke them in a uniform way. Think ‚ÄúUSB-C for AI tools.‚Äù  
  - https://github.com/microsoft/mcp  
  - https://aka.ms/mcp  
- **A2A (Agent-to-Agent):** Open protocol for structured communication between *independent agents*‚Äîsharing goals, exchanging messages/streamed updates, invoking actions, and returning results with enterprise auth/observability.  
  - https://github.com/microsoft/a2a  
  - https://aka.ms/a2a  

## What‚Äôs similar
- **Interoperability first:** both aim to decouple integrations and enable plug-and-play across ecosystems.  
- **Capability discovery & typed payloads:** each defines structured messages and standard surfaces so callers know what‚Äôs available and how to call it.  
- **Vendor-neutral ambitions:** specs meant to work across frameworks (LangChain, SK, custom stacks).  

## What‚Äôs different

| Aspect | **MCP** | **A2A** |
|---|---|---|
| **Primary link** | Agent/App ‚Üî **Tool/Resource server** | **Agent ‚Üî Agent** |
| **Purpose** | Standardize *tooling & data* access | Standardize *agent coordination* |
| **Core primitives** | Tools, Resources, Prompts; sessions/heartbeats; JSON-RPC | Tasks/goals, state, actions, results; streaming events/webhooks |
| **Discovery** | Client lists server capabilities | Agents expose capabilities/roles to each other |
| **Security posture** | Sandbox servers; least-privilege access to tools/data | Enterprise auth (e.g., Entra), mTLS, audit for cross-agent calls |
| **Typical placement** | ‚ÄúNorth‚Äìsouth‚Äù into systems/APIs | ‚ÄúEast‚Äìwest‚Äù across agents/teams |

## How they fit together (recommended)
- Wrap each specialist (Search, KB, Exec) behind **MCP servers** to expose stable tools/resources.  
- Orchestrator uses **A2A** to assign goals and exchange results with those specialists (as *agents*).  
- Net effect: **MCP for capability plumbing**, **A2A for multi-agent protocols**.  

## When to choose what
- **Use MCP** when your problem is ‚ÄúI need the same agent/app to call many tools/APIs consistently.‚Äù  
- **Use A2A** when your problem is ‚ÄúI need multiple agents (possibly from different vendors) to coordinate a task.‚Äù  

---
**References**  
- MCP Spec: https://github.com/microsoft/mcp  
- MCP Overview: https://aka.ms/mcp  
- A2A Spec: https://github.com/microsoft/a2a  
- A2A Overview: https://aka.ms/a2a

question: Summarize the history of Apple products since 2020 and retrieve the 5 most impact moment. And find related companies of each moments.
ground_truth:
## Apple products since 2020 ‚Äî snapshot

- **2020:**  
  - iPhone 12 (first 5G iPhone)  
  - Mac transition to Apple Silicon  
  - M1 Macs (Air, Pro, Mini)  
  - Ref: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2020/11/apple-unleashes-m1/  
  - Ref: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2020/06/apple-announces-mac-transition-to-apple-silicon/  

- **2021:**  
  - AirTag launches  
  - 14‚Ä≥/16‚Ä≥ MacBook Pro with M1 Pro/Max  
  - Ref: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2021/04/apple-introduces-airtag/  
  - Ref: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2021/10/apple-unleashes-m1-pro-and-m1-max/  

- **2022:**  
  - Apple Watch Ultra  
  - Ref: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2022/09/apple-unveils-apple-watch-ultra/  

- **2023:**  
  - Vision Pro unveiled  
  - M3 MacBook Pro refresh  
  - iPhone 15 line switches to USB-C  
  - Ref: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2023/06/introducing-apple-vision-pro/  
  - Ref: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2023/10/apple-unveils-new-macbook-pro-featuring-m3-chips/  
  - Ref: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2023/09/apple-announces-iphone-15-pro-and-iphone-15-pro-max/  

- **2024:**  
  - Vision Pro ships in US  
  - OLED iPad Pro with M4  
  - Apple Intelligence announced (ChatGPT integration)  
  - Ref: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2024/02/vision-pro-available-today/  
  - Ref: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2024/05/the-new-ipad-pro-is-an-outrageously-powerful-device-for-ai/  
  - Ref: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2024/06/introducing-apple-intelligence/  

- **2025:**  
  - Apple Intelligence expands across platforms  
  - Vision Pro updates continue  
  - Ref: https://www.apple.com/apple-events/june-2025/

---

## 5 most impactful moments (with related companies)

1) **Apple Silicon transition (Jun 22, 2020; M1 on Nov 10, 2020)**  
   - *Why it mattered:* Reset Mac performance/W-efficiency curve; unified Apple chip roadmap  
   - *Related companies:*  
     - TSMC (5nm chip foundry)  
     - ARM (ISA architecture)  
     - Intel (displaced incumbent)  
   - Ref: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2020/11/apple-unleashes-m1/  
   - Ref: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2020/06/apple-announces-mac-transition-to-apple-silicon/  

2) **iPhone 12 brings 5G mainstream (Oct 13, 2020)**  
   - *Related companies:*  
     - Qualcomm (Snapdragon X55 modem)  
     - Verizon (launch partner)  
   - Ref: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2020/10/apple-introduces-iphone-12/  
   - Ref: https://www.qualcomm.com/news/releases/2020/10/qualcomm-and-apple-usher-5g-era  

3) **Apple Vision Pro announcement (Jun 5, 2023) & ship (Feb 2, 2024)**  
   - *Why it mattered:* First spatial computer by Apple  
   - *Related companies:*  
     - Sony (micro-OLED display supplier)  
     - TSMC (advanced packaging)  
   - Ref: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2023/06/introducing-apple-vision-pro/  
   - Ref: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2024/02/vision-pro-available-today/  

4) **iPhone 15 switches to USB-C (Sep 12, 2023)**  
   - *Why it mattered:* End of Lightning; EU regulation-driven  
   - *Related companies:*  
     - Anker, Belkin (accessory ecosystem)  
   - Ref: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2023/09/apple-announces-iphone-15-pro-and-iphone-15-pro-max/  

5) **Apple Intelligence announced (Jun 10, 2024)**  
   - *Why it mattered:* Apple‚Äôs GenAI system-wide strategy (private cloud + on-device + ChatGPT)  
   - *Related companies:*  
     - OpenAI (integration partner)  
   - Ref: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2024/06/introducing-apple-intelligence/

question: What is the most actively researched open-source Python framework for machine learning in 2025?
ground_truth:
## What is the most actively researched open-source Python framework for machine learning in 2025?

### ‚úÖ Answer: **PyTorch**

PyTorch continues to dominate as the most actively researched and widely adopted open-source Python framework for machine learning in 2025. It is the default choice in academic papers, research repositories, and state-of-the-art model implementations.

---

### üìä Trends Overview (as of 2025)

| Framework     | Research Popularity | Industry Adoption | Performance Focus | Ecosystem |
|---------------|---------------------|-------------------|-------------------|-----------|
| **PyTorch**   | üî• Very High         | High              | Versatile         | Strong    |
| **JAX**       | üîº Rising Fast       | Growing           | High-performance  | Growing   |
| TensorFlow    | ‚¨áÔ∏è Declining         | High in legacy    | Production-grade  | Mature    |

---

### üîç Research Popularity Evidence

1. **arXiv Paper Mentions**  
   A large majority of ML/AI papers on arXiv in 2024‚Äì2025 use PyTorch in their codebase or explicitly mention it in methodology. JAX is gaining ground especially in theoretical ML and fast numerical computation research.

2. **GitHub Repositories**  
   - Hugging Face Transformers, Diffusers, and other leading open-source libraries are primarily PyTorch-first.
   - PyTorch Lightning and TorchRL have become de-facto standards in training and reinforcement learning respectively.

3. **ML Community Pulse (Kaggle, Reddit, Twitter)**  
   - PyTorch leads in community discussions and notebooks.
   - Tools like `torch.compile()` introduced in 2.0+ make it even more appealing for both research and production.

---

### üß™ Key Factors for PyTorch's Dominance

- **Dynamic Computation Graphs**: More intuitive and Pythonic, preferred for debugging and rapid prototyping.
- **Modular and Flexible**: Easy to plug in custom layers, loss functions, optimizers.
- **Strong Ecosystem**: 
  - `torchvision`, `torchaudio`, `torchtext` for multimodal inputs
  - `TorchX`, `TorchServe` for deployment
  - Support from Meta AI, OpenAI, NVIDIA, and Hugging Face

- **AI Agent & LLM Integration**: Many open-source LLM projects like LLaMA, Mistral, and Falcon are all implemented using PyTorch.

---

### üöÄ What About JAX?

JAX is the fastest growing framework among researchers working on:
- Differentiable programming
- Large-scale scientific computing
- Reinforcement learning (e.g., DeepMind‚Äôs use of JAX)

However, its ecosystem is still more niche and lower-level compared to PyTorch, making it less beginner-friendly.

---

### üè≠ What About TensorFlow/Keras?

- Still used in **production** (e.g., TFX pipelines, TensorFlow Serving).
- Legacy systems and mobile deployment (TensorFlow Lite).
- Research usage has dropped significantly.
- Less popular in open-source cutting-edge projects.

---

### üìö References

- https://pytorch.org/
- https://jax.readthedocs.io/
- https://www.tensorflow.org/
- https://huggingface.co/docs
- https://arxiv.org/
- https://github.com/pytorch
- https://github.com/google/jax
- https://paperswithcode.com/trends

question: How has climate change influenced recent natural disasters, and how have international organizations responded to them?
ground_truth:
# Climate Change, Natural Disasters, and International Responses (2024‚Äì2025)

## Summary
Climate change is intensifying the frequency and severity of natural disasters‚Äîespecially heatwaves, floods, and wildfire conditions. International organizations have stepped up with enhanced early-warning systems, humanitarian relief, adaptation funding, and the operationalization of loss and damage finance.

---

## üå°Ô∏è Climate Change Impacts on Recent Disasters

### 1. **Global Heat Records and Their Ripple Effects**
- **2024 was the hottest year ever recorded**, with unprecedented ocean and surface temperatures.
- **Ocean heat content** reached record highs, increasing the energy available to storms and disrupting marine ecosystems.
- **Sea levels** continued rising due to thermal expansion and ice melt, exacerbating coastal storm surge risks.

üìñ Sources:
- [WMO State of the Global Climate 2023](https://public.wmo.int/en/our-mandate/climate/wmo-statement-state-of-global-climate)
- [Copernicus 2024 Climate Highlights](https://climate.copernicus.eu/copernicus-2024-hottest-year-record)

---

### 2. **Extreme Rainfall and Flash Flooding**

#### üáßüá∑ *Southern Brazil Floods (May 2024)*
- Caused by persistent rainfall and blocked atmospheric flow patterns.
- Attribution study: **Climate change doubled the likelihood** of this type of event.
- Over 2 million affected, hundreds of fatalities, and major infrastructure loss.

üìñ Sources:
- [World Weather Attribution - Brazil Floods](https://www.worldweatherattribution.org/)
- [IFRC Emergency Response Brazil](https://www.ifrc.org/press-release)

#### üá¶üá™ *UAE/Oman Floods (April 2024)*
- 75+ mm of rain fell in just hours in Dubai‚Äî**the heaviest since 1949**.
- Warm Gulf waters and humid air contributed to storm intensity.

üìñ Sources:
- [Al Jazeera - UAE floods](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/4/16/dubai-hit-by-record-rainfall)
- [Gulf News - Weather breakdown](https://gulfnews.com)

---

### 3. **Wildfire Weather Intensified by Warming**

#### üá®üá¶ *Eastern Canada Wildfires (May‚ÄìJune 2023)*
- 18.5M hectares burned in 2023 (record).
- Attribution: Climate change **2‚Äì4√ó more likely** to cause such prolonged fire-conducive conditions.

üìñ Sources:
- [WWA - Canada Wildfire Attribution](https://www.worldweatherattribution.org/)
- [Canada‚Äôs National Observer](https://www.nationalobserver.com)

---

### 4. **Sea Level Rise & Coastal Storm Amplification**
- **Sea level is rising at ~4.5 mm/year**, increasing baseline flood risk in coastal cities.
- Combined with more intense storms and high tides, leads to compound flooding events.
- Saltwater intrusion threatens agriculture in deltas (e.g., Mekong, Ganges).

üìñ Sources:
- [WMO Global Climate Reports](https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=11178)
- [IPCC AR6 WG1](https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg1/)

---

## üåç International Organizational Response

### 1. **WMO/UN ‚ÄúEarly Warnings for All‚Äù (EW4All)**
- Goal: universal coverage of **early warning systems (EWS)** by 2027.
- Focus: Least Developed Countries (LDCs) and Small Island Developing States (SIDS).
- Includes **weather forecasting**, **risk communication**, and **preparedness training**.

üìñ Sources:
- [UNDP EW4All Initiative](https://www.undp.org/early-warnings)
- [WMO EW4All Dashboard](https://ew4all.org/)

---

### 2. **Humanitarian Surge via CERF (UN OCHA)**
- **Central Emergency Response Fund** allocates rapid-response funds for underfunded crises.
- In 2024‚Äì25, released emergency aid to multiple climate-linked disasters (e.g., Brazil, Sudan).
- Enabled faster delivery of food, shelter, and medical care.

üìñ Sources:
- [CERF Funding Updates](https://cerf.un.org/)
- [OCHA Situation Reports](https://reliefweb.int/organization/ocha)

---

### 3. **IFRC Operations: Red Crescent/Red Cross Movement**
- Scaled **cash and voucher assistance (CVA)** and WASH (Water, Sanitation, Hygiene) support.
- Regional Emergency Appeals deployed in:
  - Brazil floods (2024)
  - Libya floods (2023)
  - South Asia heatwaves (2024)

üìñ Sources:
- [IFRC Disaster Response Reports](https://www.ifrc.org/disaster-reports)

---

### 4. **Loss & Damage Fund Operationalization**
- Formalized at **COP28 (2023)**; launched in 2024.
- Hosted by the **World Bank** for financial management.
- Targets vulnerable nations suffering **irreversible climate impacts** (e.g., sea-level loss, cultural heritage loss).

üìñ Sources:
- [UNFCCC Loss and Damage Info Hub](https://unfccc.int/topics/adaptation-and-resilience/workstreams/loss-and-damage)
- [World Bank Fund Announcement](https://www.worldbank.org/en/news)

---

### 5. **Green Climate Fund (GCF) ‚Äì Adaptation Focus**
- GCF approved record commitments in 2024‚Äì25, emphasizing:
  - Climate-resilient infrastructure
  - Agriculture adaptation
  - Urban planning for heat and floods
- Prioritizing Africa, Pacific Islands, and South Asia.

üìñ Sources:
- [GCF Projects Database](https://www.greenclimate.fund/projects)
- [GCF 2024 Annual Report](https://www.greenclimate.fund/sites/default/files/document/annual-report-2024.pdf)

---

## ‚è≠Ô∏è Outlook
- Climate-linked disasters are now the norm, not the exception.
- Forecasting tools, cross-border data-sharing, and early warning systems are improving.
- Long-term resilience will hinge on scaling **locally-led adaptation**, **global solidarity financing**, and **low-carbon development pathways**.

If you want a breakdown by region (e.g., Africa, Asia-Pacific), disaster type (e.g., wildfire vs. flood), or funder (e.g., WB, UN, GCF), I can generate that.

question: How could advancements in quantum computing influence the future of space exploration?
ground_truth:
# Quantum Computing and the Future of Space Exploration

**Short answer:** **Quantum computing will first impact *ground* mission design and operations**‚Äînot on-board spacecraft. Expect wins in optimization-heavy tasks, then in materials and data analysis‚Äîonce hardware scales.

---

## Where it helps most

- **Mission/constellation scheduling:**  
  Formulate imaging windows, downlink, and energy/attitude constraints as QUBOs; hybrid QC (annealing/QAOA) already performs competitively on realistic satellite-planning instances.  
  [NASA QuAIL: Quantum Scheduling](https://www.nasa.gov/ames/quantum/artificial-intelligence-and-quantum-computing-at-ames/)  
  [D-Wave satellite scheduling study (arXiv:2202.11179)](https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.11179)

- **Interplanetary trajectory design:**  
  QC-backed global search over gravity assists/launch windows via QUBO/QAOA can reduce search time and broaden feasible options; early studies show promise on benchmarked cases.  
  [ESA + QC trajectory planning research (arXiv:2104.03605)](https://arxiv.org/abs/2104.03605)

- **Operations optimization:**  
  Build ‚Äúquantum-ready‚Äù encodings for tasking, resource allocation, and ground-network scheduling; NASA‚Äôs QuAIL is publishing benchmarks precisely for this.  
  [NASA QuAIL publications](https://ti.arc.nasa.gov/tech/acs/quantum/)

- **Materials & propulsion R&D (off-mission):**  
  Fault-tolerant QC could accelerate computational chemistry for cryogenic fuels, radiation-hard alloys, catalysts for ISRU, and plasma/fusion modeling. (Road-map outlook.)  
  [QED-C roadmap for quantum chemistry](https://quantumconsortium.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/QED-C-Technical-Paper-Computational-Chemistry.pdf)

- **Space data triage:**  
  Quantum ML prototypes target hyperspectral/remote-sensing classification and anomaly detection; still early-stage but active.  
  [Quantum ML for EO data (arXiv:2208.04327)](https://arxiv.org/abs/2208.04327)

---

## What not to expect (near term)

- **No proven quantum advantage yet** on end-to-end space problems; hybrids help on constrained instances, but classical baselines remain strong.  
  [Quantum Optimization in Space Applications (arXiv:2202.11179)](https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.11179)

- **On-board quantum computers are unlikely soon** (cryogenics, error correction, radiation). Expect QC to live in ground pipelines supporting design/ops.  
  [Limitations of Spaceborne QC (Nature Review Physics, 2022)](https://www.nature.com/articles/s42254-021-00358-z)

- Adjacent quantum tech (sensing/comms) will matter, but that‚Äôs *quantum sensors/networks*, not computing.  
  [Quantum sensors in space (ESA)](https://www.esa.int/Enabling_Support/Preparing_for_the_Future/Discovery_and_Preparation/Quantum_sensors_in_space)

---

## Practical roadmap (do this now)

- Pick one high-value planner (e.g., EO tasking or Mars transfer search). Build a **QUBO/QAOA** formulation; benchmark against your current solver; run on a hybrid quantum service.  
  [D-Wave hybrid solver access](https://www.dwavesys.com/take-leap)

- Adopt **QuAIL-style benchmark sets** and publish parity plots (cost vs. wall-clock) to track when QC helps.  
  [NASA QuAIL benchmarks](https://ti.arc.nasa.gov/tech/acs/quantum/)

- Keep QC in the loop as a **coprocessor** in HPC workflows: classical generates candidates ‚Üí QC refines/filters ‚Üí classical verifies.  
  [Hybrid workflow examples (arXiv:2304.06600)](https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06600)

---

## Bottom line

**Near-term = hybrid optimization aid**  
**Mid-term = broader ops integration**  
**Long-term (fault-tolerant) = step-change in materials and high-fidelity mission sims**

question: Are there any notable examples of blockchain technology being used in renewable energy systems?
ground_truth:
# Notable Examples of Blockchain Technology in Renewable Energy Systems

Blockchain is increasingly being explored and applied in renewable energy for its transparency, decentralization, and security. Here are several notable real-world applications, categorized by use case:

---

## ‚ö° Peer-to-Peer Energy Trading

### 1. **Brooklyn Microgrid (LO3 Energy, USA)**
- **Location:** Brooklyn, New York
- **Technology:** Ethereum-based blockchain
- **Purpose:** Facilitates peer-to-peer (P2P) energy trading among neighbors using rooftop solar panels.
- **Mechanism:** Residents with excess solar energy can sell it directly to neighbors using smart meters and blockchain for transaction validation.
- **Impact:** Early proof of concept that showed community-based energy sharing is feasible.

**Reference:**
- [https://www.brooklyn.energy/](https://www.brooklyn.energy/)
- [https://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/how-blockchain-could-give-us-a-smarter-energy-grid](https://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/how-blockchain-could-give-us-a-smarter-energy-grid)

---

### 2. **Power Ledger (Australia, Thailand, India, Japan)**
- **Location:** Fremantle, Perth (Australia); Bangkok (Thailand); and other pilot sites in Asia.
- **Technology:** Power Ledger blockchain platform
- **Purpose:** Enables consumers to trade excess solar power with each other via a secure and transparent platform.
- **Example:** In Bangkok, Power Ledger partnered with BCPG and the Metropolitan Electricity Authority (MEA) to implement P2P energy trading in the T77 urban precinct.
- **Status:** Active in pilot and early commercial phases globally.

**Reference:**
- [https://www.powerledger.io/](https://www.powerledger.io/)
- [https://www.smart-energy.com/industry-sectors/blockchain/power-ledger-launches-peer-to-peer-energy-trading-in-thailand/](https://www.smart-energy.com/industry-sectors/blockchain/power-ledger-launches-peer-to-peer-energy-trading-in-thailand/)

---

## üß† Grid Stabilization and Flexibility

### 3. **TenneT √ó sonnen √ó IBM (Germany/Netherlands)**
- **Participants:** TenneT (TSO), sonnen (battery storage), IBM (blockchain)
- **Purpose:** Use decentralized home battery systems to stabilize the power grid.
- **Technology:** IBM Hyperledger blockchain tracks and coordinates battery charging/discharging based on grid needs.
- **Impact:** Pilot showed blockchain can support real-time decentralized energy balancing.

**Reference:**
- [https://newsroom.ibm.com/2017-05-04-TenneT-uses-IBM-Blockchain-to-Balance-the-Power-Grid-with-Distributed-Energy](https://newsroom.ibm.com/2017-05-04-TenneT-uses-IBM-Blockchain-to-Balance-the-Power-Grid-with-Distributed-Energy)

---

### 4. **Equigy (EU-wide TSO Consortium)**
- **Founders:** TenneT (Netherlands & Germany), Swissgrid (Switzerland), Terna (Italy), TransnetBW (Germany)
- **Technology:** Based on a DLT platform to integrate Distributed Energy Resources (DERs) into balancing markets.
- **Function:** Households and small-scale producers can offer flexibility (from EVs, batteries, etc.) directly to grid operators.
- **Status:** Ongoing deployment in multiple European countries.

**Reference:**
- [https://www.equigy.com/](https://www.equigy.com/)

---

## üßæ Renewable Energy Certificates (REC) and Tracking

### 5. **SP Group ‚Äì Blockchain REC Marketplace (Singapore)**
- **Launched:** 2018
- **Operator:** Singapore Power (SP Group)
- **Function:** Allows enterprises to buy/sell verified Renewable Energy Certificates using blockchain.
- **Tech:** Custom blockchain infrastructure to ensure verifiability and traceability of REC transactions.
- **Notable Feature:** Multinational companies use it to meet sustainability goals.

**Reference:**
- [https://www.spgroup.com.sg/what-we-do/sustainability/blockchain-rec](https://www.spgroup.com.sg/what-we-do/sustainability/blockchain-rec)

---

### 6. **Energy Web Foundation ‚Äì EW Origin**
- **Type:** Sector-specific blockchain for energy (Energy Web Chain)
- **Use Case:** EW Origin is an open-source toolkit to issue, track, and retire Energy Attribute Certificates (EACs), such as RECs or Guarantees of Origin (GOs).
- **Adoption:** Used in projects across Europe, the US, and Asia by utilities, grid operators, and enterprises.

**Reference:**
- [https://www.energyweb.org/technology/ew-origin/](https://www.energyweb.org/technology/ew-origin/)
- [https://www.energyweb.org/](https://www.energyweb.org/)

---

## ü™ô Tokenization and Smart Contracts

### 7. **WePower √ó Elering (Estonia)**
- **Partnership:** Blockchain energy startup WePower and Estonia‚Äôs national grid operator, Elering.
- **Pilot:** Tokenized energy contracts on the blockchain tied to actual production data from the Estonian grid.
- **Goal:** Enable fractional ownership and trading of future renewable energy production.
- **Outcome:** Successfully tokenized and uploaded 26,000 hours and 24 TWh of historical energy data.

**Reference:**
- [https://medium.com/wepower/first-nationwide-energy-tokenization-project-in-estonia-6f3f5868701](https://medium.com/wepower/first-nationwide-energy-tokenization-project-in-estonia-6f3f5868701)
- [https://www.elering.ee/en/news/wepower-and-elering-pilot-worlds-first-nationwide-energy-tokenization](https://www.elering.ee/en/news/wepower-and-elering-pilot-worlds-first-nationwide-energy-tokenization)

---

## Summary Table

| Project                     | Country         | Type                     | Status           |
|----------------------------|------------------|--------------------------|------------------|
| Brooklyn Microgrid         | USA              | P2P Trading              | Pilot            |
| Power Ledger               | Australia/Asia   | P2P + Grid + REC         | Scaling          |
| TenneT √ó sonnen √ó IBM      | Germany/NL       | Grid Stability           | Completed Pilot  |
| Equigy                     | EU               | Grid Flexibility         | Ongoing          |
| SP Group REC Marketplace   | Singapore        | REC Trading              | Active           |
| Energy Web (EW Origin)     | Global           | REC Tracking             | Active           |
| WePower √ó Elering          | Estonia          | Energy Tokenization      | Completed Pilot  |

---

## Closing Notes

These examples illustrate blockchain's potential in:
- Enabling **transactive energy systems** via P2P trading
- Improving **grid resilience and load balancing**
- Enhancing **transparency and traceability** in renewable energy certification
- Supporting **new financial models** like fractional ownership of energy production

Many projects remain in pilot stages, but several (e.g., SP Group, Power Ledger, Energy Web) are operational at national or international levels.

question: Please explain the traditional Korean food and its characteristics in Chungcheong area.
ground_truth:
Here‚Äôs the **Chungcheong** (Chungcheongnam-do & Chungcheongbuk-do) food snapshot‚Äîshort and practical.

## Core characteristics
- **Milder, cleaner seasoning** than many other regions; heavy use of soy-based **jang** (ganjang/doenjang) and restrained chili heat. Fermentation (jang, jeotgal) is foundational. [source](turn0search8) [source](turn0search15)  
- **Two-source pantry:** west-coast mudflats/sea (Chungnam) + inland rivers/plains (Chungbuk) ‚Üí seafood + freshwater produce; lots of soups, stews, and **gukbap** (rice-in-soup). [source](turn0search0) [source](turn1search4)

## Signature things to try
- **Ganggyeong jeotgal (fermented salted seafood), Nonsan** ‚Äî one of Korea‚Äôs largest/oldest salted-seafood markets; hallmark Chungnam seasoning. Visit in Oct for the Jeotgal Festival. [source](turn0search1) [source](turn0search5) [source](turn1search6)  
- **Gulbap (oyster rice), Boryeong** ‚Äî west-coast oysters cooked with rice; also grilled/steamed oysters and oyster kalguksu common around Cheonbuk Oyster Complex. [source](turn3search1) [source](turn3search6)  
- **Gamtae (delicate mudflat seaweed), Seosan‚ÄìGarorim Bay** ‚Äî rare, winter-harvested seaweed now prized by chefs; uniquely grows on mudflats in Garorim Bay. [source](turn4search1) [source](turn1search8)  
- **Olgaenggi-guk (marsh-snail soup), Cheongju & Chungbuk** ‚Äî earthy, doenjang-based soup with snails, chives, and curled mallow; a representative Chungcheong comfort food. [source](turn2search12) [source](turn2search5)  
- **Janggukbap (soy-seasoned beef broth over rice)** ‚Äî classic market-style gukbap with ganjang-seasoned beef stock and vegetables. [source](turn1search7) [source](turn0search10)  
- **Muk (buckwheat/acorn jellies)** ‚Äî long associated with Chungcheong market food culture; often sliced thin, dressed simply. [source](turn2search14)  
- **Chestnut dishes (bam-bap, snacks), Gongju/Buyeo** ‚Äî region is renowned for chestnuts; chestnut rice and chestnut-based sides are common. [source](turn3search7) [source](turn3search2)

## What to expect on the table
- **Soups/stews first:** maeuntang (spicy fish stew) on the coast; freshwater fish stews inland; plenty of simple soy-seasoned broths. [source](turn2search15)  
- **Fermented depth, not overload:** jeotgal to season kimchi/banchan; jang defines the saltiness/umami more than raw salt. [source](turn0search1) [source](turn0search8)

If you want a 1-day tasting route (oysters ‚Üí jeotgal ‚Üí muk ‚Üí olgaenggi-guk), say the word and I‚Äôll map it.

question: Tell me about the latest political situation for the U.S. and stock trends today.
ground_truth:
**Date context:** August 7, 2025 KST (August 6 ET)

---

# üá∫üá∏ U.S. Political Situation ‚Äì In-Depth

## üè¶ Executive Order Targeting Banks Over Alleged Political Bias

The White House is finalizing an executive order directing regulators like the FDIC, OCC, and CFPB to investigate large financial institutions‚Äîspecifically JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America‚Äîfor alleged political discrimination in account closures, also known as ‚Äúde-banking.‚Äù 

This follows unsubstantiated claims by Donald Trump and some conservative groups that banks have systematically denied service or closed accounts based on political views. The order will likely authorize penalties if political bias is found in customer de-risking processes.

- Critics argue that banks act based on AML/KYC risk, not ideology.
- JPMorgan and BofA deny accusations of bias.
- This move aligns with Trump‚Äôs 2025 campaign messaging focused on anti-establishment grievances.

**Sources:**
- https://www.reuters.com/world/us/white-house-target-banks-trump-claims-discrimination-2025-08-06/
- https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2025/08/05/trump-de-banking-conservatives/

## üáÆüá≥ U.S. Tariffs on Indian Imports Amid Trade Tensions

On August 6, the U.S. announced a new **25% tariff** on a wide range of Indian imports. This move comes after failed trade talks and U.S. criticism of India's continued purchase of discounted Russian oil.

### Key points:
- New tariffs affect apparel, electronics, auto parts, and jewelry.
- The total tariff burden on some goods now exceeds 50%.
- The administration says the tariffs will ‚Äúrebalance‚Äù trade fairness and discourage India‚Äôs alignment with Russia.

India has not yet responded with retaliatory tariffs but has expressed ‚Äúdeep disappointment.‚Äù

**Sources:**
- https://www.reuters.com/world/india/trump-imposes-additional-25-tariff-indian-goods-relations-hit-new-low-2025-08-06/
- https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/08/06/us-imposes-new-tariffs-on-india-over-russia-ties

## üçé Apple‚Äôs $100 Billion U.S. Investment Pledge

The White House confirmed that Apple will invest **$100 billion more** into U.S.-based manufacturing, adding to its previously announced $500 billion reshoring plan. The investment focuses on:

- Expanding advanced manufacturing facilities (e.g., server components for AI).
- Building R&D centers in North Carolina and Ohio.
- Workforce development initiatives tied to semiconductor and AI hardware assembly.

The pledge follows ongoing tariff uncertainty with China and is framed as part of the U.S. industrial policy to boost tech sovereignty.

**Sources:**
- https://www.reuters.com/business/retail-consumer/apple-pledge-100-billion-us-manufacturing-white-house-official-says-2025-08-06/
- https://financialbuzz.com/apple-pledges-additional-100-billion-to-u-s-manufacturing/
- https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/technology/tech-news/apple-to-announce-100-billion-manufacturing-investment-in-us-white-house-official/articleshow/123145828.cms

## üèõÔ∏è Congress in Recess ‚Äî Government Shutdown Looms

Congress is in August recess. However, a **September 30 deadline** to pass funding bills raises the specter of a government shutdown.

### Background:
- Appropriations negotiations remain stalled between House Republicans and Senate Democrats.
- Trump-aligned factions demand cuts to DOJ/FBI budgets and funding conditions on immigration enforcement.
- A continuing resolution (CR) is being considered, but its passage is uncertain due to intra-party rifts.

If no action is taken by October 1, parts of the federal government could shut down.

**Sources:**
- https://www.politico.com/news/2025/08/04/congress-is-on-summer-break-funding-chaos-awaits-00489552
- https://www.politico.com/news/2025/08/01/senate-passes-first-funding-package-ahead-of-september-shutdown-cliff-00489731

---

# üìà U.S. Stock Market Trends ‚Äì August 6 ET

## üîº Midday Market Movement

Markets traded slightly higher on renewed expectations of a **Fed rate cut in September** and optimism over corporate earnings:

- **Dow Jones:** +0.01%
- **S&P 500:** +0.12%
- **Nasdaq:** +0.21%

Positive sentiment was partially offset by:
- A weak showing from AMD and Super Micro Computer, which dragged tech.
- Cautious outlooks from logistics and industrials over rising tariffs.

Rate cut odds rose from ~47% to ~89% after dovish Fed commentary and soft macro data.

**Sources:**
- https://www.reuters.com/business/sp-500-nasdaq-lifted-by-earnings-fed-hopes-2025-08-06/
- https://www.investing.com/news/economy-news/wall-st-futures-edge-up-amid-fed-rate-cut-optimism-earnings-in-focus-4172451

## üîΩ Previous Day Recap ‚Äì August 5

On Tuesday, the market closed lower:

- **Dow:** ‚àí0.1%
- **S&P 500:** ‚àí0.5%
- **Nasdaq:** ‚àí0.7%

Main factors:
- Investor anxiety over escalating U.S.-India tariff war.
- Weaker-than-expected ISM Services Index showing stagnation in July.

**Sources:**
- https://www.reuters.com/business/wall-street-turns-negative-economic-data-tariff-uncertainty-weigh-2025-08-05/

---

# üßæ Summary Table

| Topic                          | Highlights                                                                 |
|-------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Bank executive order           | White House probing large banks for political bias in de-banking practices |
| India tariff escalation        | New 25% tariff hits key sectors amid breakdown in trade relations          |
| Apple manufacturing pledge     | $100B U.S. investment as part of tech reshoring strategy                   |
| Government funding risk        | Shutdown looms as Congress recesses with no budget consensus               |
| Market tone                    | Slight gains on rate-cut hopes, volatility from tariffs and weak services  |

---

# üìö Sources and References

- White House banking EO:  
  https://www.reuters.com/world/us/white-house-target-banks-trump-claims-discrimination-2025-08-06/

- U.S.‚ÄìIndia tariffs:

  https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/08/06/us-imposes-new-tariffs-on-india-over-russia-ties  

- Apple manufacturing:  
  https://www.reuters.com/business/retail-consumer/apple-pledge-100-billion-us-manufacturing-white-house-official-says-2025-08-06/  
  https://financialbuzz.com/apple-pledges-additional-100-billion-to-u-s-manufacturing/  
  https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/technology/tech-news/apple-to-announce-100-billion-manufacturing-investment-in-us-white-house-official/articleshow/123145828.cms

question: Was the programming language used for Apollo 11‚Äôs onboard computer created before the first peer-reviewed article describing backpropagation?
ground_truth:
**Was the programming language used for Apollo 11‚Äôs onboard computer created before the first peer-reviewed article describing backpropagation?**

**Answer:** Yes.

---

## Detailed Explanation

### üõ∞Ô∏è Apollo 11 and its Onboard Computer Language

Apollo 11‚Äôs onboard computer was the **Apollo Guidance Computer (AGC)**, developed by MIT Instrumentation Laboratory. The AGC was programmed using a specialized low-level language known as **AGC assembly** (also called **AGC assembly language** or **AGC assembler**).

- **Development timeline:**
  - Work on the AGC started around **1961‚Äì1962**.
  - The AGC assembly language was actively developed and in use by **1965**.
  - Apollo 11 landed on the Moon in **July 1969**.

- **Key characteristics of AGC assembly:**
  - Custom-designed for the AGC‚Äôs 15-bit word architecture.
  - Very memory-efficient due to tight hardware constraints (just 36 KB of read-only memory and 2 KB of RAM).
  - Source code is available and preserved (e.g., the Apollo 11 guidance code: [https://github.com/chrislgarry/Apollo-11](https://github.com/chrislgarry/Apollo-11)).

- **Instruction set and development tools:**
  - The language featured symbolic instructions like `TC`, `AD`, `MASK`, `CAF`, `TCAA`, etc.
  - Tools like **YUL assembler** were used to translate symbolic code into binary.

**Sources:**
- [MIT AGC History](https://www.ibiblio.org/apollo/)
- [AGC source code GitHub mirror](https://github.com/chrislgarry/Apollo-11)
- [The Apollo Guidance Computer: Architecture and Operation](https://www.doneyles.com/LM/Tales.html)

---

### ü§ñ Backpropagation and Neural Networks

Backpropagation is a core algorithm used for training **artificial neural networks** by calculating gradients via the **chain rule**.

- **Historical development:**
  - The mathematical principles were known earlier (e.g., by Paul Werbos in his 1974 Ph.D. thesis).
  - However, the **first widely recognized peer-reviewed publication** of the algorithm was by **David E. Rumelhart, Geoffrey E. Hinton, and Ronald J. Williams** in **1986**:
    - **Title:** Learning representations by back-propagating errors
    - **Published in:** *Nature*, 1986
    - This paper sparked a resurgence in neural network research.

**Sources:**
- Rumelhart, Hinton & Williams (1986): [https://www.nature.com/articles/323533a0](https://www.nature.com/articles/323533a0)
- Werbos Ph.D. thesis (1974): [https://www.proquest.com/openview/4adbb3d9cf63a9fbb9e3fa2f3771f1ad/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=18750](https://www.proquest.com/openview/4adbb3d9cf63a9fbb9e3fa2f3771f1ad/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=18750)

---

## üß† Final Comparison

| Aspect                            | Apollo 11 AGC Assembly Language      | Backpropagation (peer-reviewed)   |
|-----------------------------------|--------------------------------------|-----------------------------------|
| Developed/Published               | ~1965                                | 1986                              |
| Used in Operational Mission       | Apollo 11, 1969                      | Not used in practice until much later |
| Type                              | Low-level assembly for embedded systems | Algorithm for training neural networks |
| Major Publication                 | Not applicable (in-house at MIT/NSA) | *Nature*, Rumelhart et al. (1986) |

---

## ‚úÖ Conclusion

The AGC programming language predates the first peer-reviewed publication on backpropagation by **more than two decades**.
